II.        RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis  

A. 
 
2. 
Livestock and related enterprises and services play a prominent role in the economy of 
Bangladesh  and  involve  large  numbers  of  rural  households.  The  livestock  subsector  is  labor 
intensive and its activities are evenly spread throughout the country, with an estimated 85% of 
all rural households owning some animals or poultry. The subsector contributes about 3% to the 
gross  domestic  product  and  provides  full-time  employment  for  about  20%  of  the  rural 
population. Over the last decade, changes in the livestock population have reflected the decline 
in  grazing  land  area  because  of  urban  expansion,  and  the  increased  market  opportunities  in 
urban  areas  for  higher  quality  and  more  diverse  foods.  The  total  number  of  beef  and  buffalo 
numbers  (23  million)  has  only  increased  marginally,  while  the  number  of  dairy  cows  has 
increased by about 50% as the demand for fresh milk has risen. Overall, from 1995 to 2000 the 
annual average growth in production was 2.7% for milk and milk products, 4.3% for meat, and 
7.7% for eggs, indicating an increasing demand for livestock products as a result of economic 
growth,  higher  incomes,  and  urbanization.  Goat  and  sheep  (14  million)  have  increased  only 
marginally,  but  poultry  numbers  have  risen  by  72%  with  a  significant  growth  in  commercial 
operations around urban areas. 
 
3. 
The livestock subsector is the primary source of animal power for land cultivation, which 
has  historically  been  its  most  important  contribution.  In  recent  years,  however,  the  subsector 
has  provided  an  increasing  volume  of  eggs,  broiler  meat,  and  milk  to  the  domestic  market. 
Although the per capita consumption of animal and poultry products remains low, the demand 
for  milk,  meat,  and  eggs  will  be  proportionally  stronger  as  household  incomes  increase.  The 
subsector  has  also  been  an  important  foreign  exchange  earner  through  the  export  of  hides, 
skins, and leather products. From 1995 to 2000, exports of these products earned about $190 
million  per  year  accounting  for  up  to  5%  of  foreign  export  earnings  and  made  them  the  fourth 
largest foreign exchange earner after garments, jute, and shrimp.   
 
B. 
 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  review  of  the  Bangladesh  livestock  sector2 
4. 
concluded that, although the subsector makes meaningful contributions to the economy and to 
employment,  it  has  the  potential  to  expand  its  production  base  and  significantly  improve  rural 
livelihoods  and  incomes,  especially  among  the  poor.  Most  livestock  are  still  managed 
traditionally.  Feeding  is  inadequate  and  vulnerability  to  diseases  is  prevalent.  Production 
coefficients  are  among  the  lowest  in  Asia,  and  all  types  of  livestock  record  high  mortalities. 
Indigenous  breeds  of  animals  and  poultry  predominate,  but  they  lack  the  genetic  potential  to 
realize  the  benefits  of  better  management  and  disease  control.  The  technology  and  inputs 
required  to  improve  livestock  coefficients  and  overall  production  are  simple  and  proven,  but

5. 
The ADB livestock sector review noted that nongovernment organizations (NGOs) have 
developed  alternative  approaches  to  livestock  improvement  that  have  been  successful  in 
introducing  better  management  systems  and  improved  breeds.  The  NGO  concept  treats 
livestock  production  as  a  distinct  farming  enterprise  within  the  farming  system.  Small  farmers 
have been offered a technical and microfinance package with the relevant supporting services. 
Participating households have dramatically outperformed traditional management systems and 
significantly increased their overall income. A particular focus has been on landless households 
with the development of inexpensive improved  poultry and other livestock enterprises. Income 
from  these  activities  has  made  a  major  contribution  to  poverty  reduction  in  the  target  areas. 
These  households  have  not  been  able  to  access  microfinance  through  the  formal  banking 
system  to  invest  in  livestock  enterprises.  The  provision  of  microfinance  and  technical  support 
through NGOs addresses this need. 
 
The  Government’s  planning  and  poverty  reduction  strategies  recognize  the  success  of 
6. 
this new approach to livestock development and its effectiveness in raising incomes among the 
poorest  rural  households.  The  national  strategy  for  economic  growth,  poverty  reduction  and 
social development3 places special emphasis on the role of the private sector and of NGOs in 
livestock  development.  The  strategy  recommends  that  NGO  activities  concentrate  on  target 
group formation, training, extension, microfinance disbursement, supervision and recovery, and 
conducting  socioeconomic  studies.  The  strategy  also  stresses  that  public  sector  projects  with 
similar  components  should  be  implemented  by  NGOs.  The  strategy  emphasizes  the  need  for 
the livestock sector to create additional income in rural areas through both service delivery and 
production. A plan for the future development of the livestock subsector is in Appendix 1. 
 
In  its  country  operations  strategy4  and  its  partnership  agreement  on  poverty  reduction5 
7. 
with  the  Government,  ADB  has  recognized  the  important  role  that  the  livestock  subsector  can 
play in poverty reduction by providing food, cash income, and employment opportunities for the 
rural  poor.  The  country  strategy  recommends  that  ADB’s  future  involvement  in  the  livestock 
subsector should be to provide microfinance and policy support prioritizing the (i) development

subsector; and (iv) support to DLS in reorienting its policies and service delivery.

50% in the surveyed households. In addition, monthly household expenditures for food, clothing, 
and school expenses; and household savings7 showed significant (25–75%) increases. 
 
9. 
The  PLDP  demonstrated  that  it  is  possible  to  successfully  deliver  a  large  number  of 
technically  supported,  microfinanced  livestock  improvement  packages  through  PKSF  and  its 
partner NGOs with DLS technical support. Impacts were positive on the income and standard of 
living of poor households. However, a key lesson learned is that the PLDP’s prescriptive design 
and targets did not provide the NGOs with sufficient flexibility to engage a wide range of poor 
households, particularly the ultrapoor. Similarly, the project design limited beneficiaries in their 
choice  of  investment  enterprise,  and  opportunities  to  exploit  local  marketing  and  resource 
advantages were lost. The proposed Project will offer a more extensive menu of enterprises to 
maximize  livestock  development  opportunities,  and  enterprise  selection  will  be  demand  driven 
to allow local skills and production advantages to be fully used. 
 
10. 
Other external assistance to the livestock subsector has similarly supported small farmer 
development  initiatives  (Appendix  2).  The  International  Fund  for  Agricultural  Development 
(IFAD)  and  Danish  International  Development  Assistance  (Danida)  have  funded  smallholder 
livestock  development  projects.  DLS  executed  these  projects  in  collaboration  with  several 
national NGOs. Consistent with the Government’s policy directives, the more recent externally 
funded projects (PLDP, the Community Livestock and Dairy Development Project of the United 
Nations Development Programme, and a recently approved IFAD microfinance project), used or 
will  use  PKSF  and  participating  NGOs  as  executing  agencies,  with  DLS  providing  technical 
support.   
 
11. 
A  reorientation  of  the  role  of  DLS  in  the  subsector  will  encourage  increased  private 
sector  investment  and  provision  of  services.  The  continued  presence  of  DLS  in  providing

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Economic Impacts 

The Project is justified on both efficiency and equity grounds. There is an undersupply of 
54. 
community development and microfinance services in the target areas. These deficiencies will 
be addressed by providing training and microfinance services to local communities to improve 
their participation in development planning and management of their enterprises. The enhanced 
human and social capital of the beneficiaries will be a significant outcome. Equity issues will be 
addressed  by  ensuring  that  locally  identified  community  needs  are  incorporated  in  the 
development  plans.  The  Project  will  reduce  poverty  through  its  expected  positive  impact  on 
household incomes. As the outputs from project-financed activities will be largely determined by 
a  community  demand-driven  process,  it  is  difficult  to  predict  the  actual  mix  and  scale  of  the 
outputs. Furthermore, it  is not possible to quantify the long-term benefits of the human capital 
development  activities  in  the  community  and  capacity  development  components.  Therefore,  a 
full  benefit-cost  analysis  for  the  overall  project  was  considered  impractical.  The  summary 
economic analysis is in Appendix 9. 
 
55. 
The  main  project  benefits  will  be  the  incremental  production  of  eggs,  young  chickens, 
hens,  fattened  calves  and  goats,  milk,  and  milk  products.  The  incremental  output  will  be 
consumed by the beneficiaries, or sold in local and regional markets. Average increases of at 
least  20%  are  expected  in  the  annual  incomes  of  poor  families.  Intermediate  outputs  such  as 
improved  day-old  chicks,  feed  ingredients,  and  hides  and  skins  will  also  be  sold  to  local 
producers.  Livestock  services  such  as  extension  and  poultry  vaccinations  will  be  in  demand, 
particularly  as  livestock  inputs  are  increasingly  provided  by  the  private  sector.  There  will  be  a 
significant increase in beneficiary nutritional levels that has not been quantified. The Project will 
also provide environmental benefits—manure produced by cattle and poultry is used as fertilizer 
and domestic fuel in rural areas. 
 
B. 

Poverty Reduction Impacts 

56. 
Investments to develop the livestock subsector have a direct impact on the income and 
nonincome dimensions of poverty across all income groups. This is particularly relevant to the 
segment of the population living in absolute poverty that is categorized as hard core poor. The 
inability of the poor to access resources, both financial (microfinance, employment) and social 
(education, health, skill development, training, and capacity building), is a significant obstacle in 
the development of their human capital, which is a key factor for sustainable poverty reduction. 
There are 2.9 million households in the project area, and it is estimated that about 72% of them 
(2.1 million) are below the poverty line. The Project will assist 660,000 households (31% of the 
poor  households),  concentrating  its  activities  on  the  landless  and  households  with  women 
heads that are among the poorest of the poor. 
 
57. 
Access to a regular and usable flow of financial and social resources through the Project 
will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  by  (i)  raising  the  beneficiaries’  levels  of  empowerment, 
particularly  with  regard  to  accessing  services;  (ii)  increasing  the  number  of  organized  farmer 
(female  and  male)  groups;  (iii)  increasing  the  demand  for  labor  because  of  the  availability  of 
resources  for  economic  activities;  (iv)  raising  household  incomes  through  employment 
generation;  (v)  enhancing  the  nutritional  status  of  households  through  the  consumption  of 
livestock  and  dairy  products;  (vi)  increasing  women’s  employment  opportunities;  and  (vii) 
encouraging  the  growth  of  environment-friendly  economic  enterprises.  A  summary  poverty 
reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 10.

58. 
Direct  and  quantifiable  project  benefits  will  accrue  to  both  primary  (poor  households, 
particularly  those  headed  by  women)  and  secondary  (NGOs  and  other  service  providers) 
beneficiaries. The estimated annual margin (or benefit) from a poultry key rearer enterprise, for 
example,  is  Tk3,200  ($56).  Adoption  of  such  an  enterprise  will  have  a  significant  impact  on

marginal categories; and over 30% for beneficiaries in very poor households and those headed 
by  women.  In  total,  it  is  expected  that  the  Project  will  reach  at  least  250,000  households  who

C. 

Social Impacts 

59. 
The Project will promote improved and easy access to skills development and capacity- 
building  resources  and  services.  These  social  benefits  will  lead  to  employment  generation  for 
the  poor,  especially  through  the  development  of  technical  skills  among  women  project 
participants.  Social  benefits  will  also  be  derived  through  increased  opportunities  for  education 
and health care, and improved nutritional status of families in general, and children and women 
in particular. Empowering the poor to demand and gain access to services and resources will be 
a long-term benefit of the Project. The use of selection criteria that target poor areas for project 
interventions will ensure that investments in the livestock subsector are directed to poorer areas 
of  the  northwestern  region  of  the  country.  If  during  implementation  it  becomes  apparent  that 
indigenous  people  are  a  major  potential  beneficiary  group  in  some  of  the  new  project 
subdistricts, then need-based strategies will be developed together with a detailed plan of action 
to address their specific needs.  
 
D. 

Gender and Development Issues 

60.  Women  constitute  49.4%  of  the  population  in  the  project  area,  and  17.8%  of  the  2.9 
million  households  are  headed  by  females.  The  preparatory  socioeconomic  surveys  indicate 
that these households are often among the poorest in the project area. Over 70% of the female 
population is engaged in livestock rearing. Faced with the double impediments of a marginalized 
status in the family, community, and society, and lack of negotiating skills, women have had little 
or  no  real  participation  in  decision  making.  The  Project  will  provide  opportunities  to  address 
these concerns by (i) creating an enabling environment for women’s participation at all stages of 
project  planning  and  implementation;  (ii)  ensuring  that  project  benefits  reach  100%  of  the 
identified  households,  particularly  those  with  female  heads;  (iii)  generating  employment 
opportunities  for  women  by  involving  them  not  only  in  livestock  rearing  but  also  in  marketing 
products  and  supply  of  inputs  like  feed;  (iv)  facilitating  linkages  of  the  women  beneficiaries  to 
different  support  resources  for  sustainability  of  their  livelihood;  and  (v)  facilitating  social  and 
economic empowerment through formation of women farmer groups to gain increased access to 
resources  and  participation  in  project  activities.  Women  will  also  be  supported  to  develop 
entrepreneurship  skills  and  become  entrepreneurs  by  establishing  linkages  with  microfinance 
institutions,  government  agencies,  and  NGOs.  They  will  also  be  trained  to  manage  economic 
enterprises.  The  gender  specialists  in  the  NGOs  will  formulate  specific  strategies  to  address 
gender issues in the Project, including formation of small-scale joint ventures and mechanisms 
to  generate  home-based  income  activities  for  the  older  women  in  the  households.  A  gender 
action plan is in Appendix 11.

The  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  has  indicated  that  the  high  population 
pressure  from  both  humans  and  livestock  leads  to  some  pollution  of  waterways  and  ponds.  It 
was found that none of the surveyed households had any waste treatment system, nor had they 
any  precise  understanding  of  the  effects  of  a  degraded  environment.  The  Project  will  finance 
stall-feeding  or  tethered  systems  for  larger  animals  and  semiscavenging  systems  for  poultry. 
The by-products from these enterprises will be recycled as crop fertilizer, or used as domestic 
fuel.  The  Project  will  promote  the  use  of  biogas  digesters  to  reduce  dependence  on  dung  for 
fuel.  The  Project  will  include  education  on  environmental  responsibilities  and  management  in 
the NGO and farmer training programs to develop community consciousness of environmental 
issues  that  will  extend  beyond  the  life  of  the  Project.  The  design  of  markets,  slaughter  slabs, 
and  milk  treatment  stations  will  include  effective  and  environmentally  sound  waste  and  water 
disposal systems. It is believed that the Project enterprise activities will have a minimal adverse 
impact on the environment. The project training programs will significantly assist in developing 
better  environment  management  practices  in  rural  areas.  Staff  of  the  participating  NGOs  and 
the  PMU  will  monitor  compliance  with  the  conditions  specified  in  the  project  environmental 
clearances,  with  the  periodic  assistance  of  an  environmental  monitoring  and  evaluation 
specialist. The summary IEE is in Appendix 12.

Risks 

62. 
Compared  with  the  PLDP,  the  Project’s  participatory  planning  approach  will  give  the 
beneficiaries  flexibility  in  selecting  enterprises  and  ensure  that  the  individual  makes  the  best 
possible  choice.  This  feature  will  also  allow  participants  to  move  away  from  investment  areas 
that become unprofitable or distorted by externalities such as unfair trade practices. Favorable 
product  prices  are  needed  to  provide  farmers  with  the  expected  financial  benefits.  The  price 
assumptions used in the financial and economic analyses are conservative, and experience in 
the PLDP indicates that the risk of adverse producer prices is minimal; most of the products are 
consumed or marketed locally, with little outside competition at lower prices. Also, the growing 
consumption  levels  of  livestock  products  in  Bangladesh  indicate  that  household  consumption 
and  local  market  demand  will  readily  dispose  of  the  Project’s  incremental  output  without  a 
significant  adverse  impact  on  producer  prices.  The  Government  will  take  all  necessary 
measures to mitigate the risk of the outbreak of livestock diseases, including the increased use 
of  vaccines  supplied  by  the  private  sector,  the  presence  of  CEWs  to  vaccinate  animals,  and 
improved DLS disease diagnostic services. In the PLDP, not all of the funds allocated for credit 
were used, not because of a lack of demand for credit (para. 12), but because NGOs recycled 
loans  using  funds  originally  borrowed  from  PKSF,  and  beneficiaries  used  savings.  The  risk  of 
ADB  loan  funds  not  being  used  in  the  Project  has  been  mitigated  because  recycling  of  credit 
and  the  use  of  PKSF  and  NGOs’  own  resources  were  taken  into  account  in  designing  the 
Project, with only $7.5 million being provided through the ADB loan for credit (Table A4.2)    
 
63. 
The Project will promote increased private sector production and delivery of inputs in the 
livestock  subsector.  Government  participation  in  such  activities  is  being  reduced  in  the  PLDP. 
To  ensure  that  this  process  will  continue  and  input  subsidies  will  be  eliminated,  a  specific 
assurance has been provided in this regard (Assurances, [xi]). DLS is committed to institutional 
reform (para. 31). In addition, because private firms already supply the majority of such inputs, 
failure to eliminate the subsidies would not pose a threat to the successful implementation of the 
Project.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 

Rationale 

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
The Project is justified on both efficiency and equity grounds. The need for the Project 
1. 
arises  from  the  undersupply  of  community  development  services  in  the  project  area  and 
underinvestment in microfinance delivery services. These deficiencies will largely be addressed 
by providing training and support services to local people to improve their ability to access the 
resources–both physical and financial–required for income improvement. Enhancing the human 
and  social  capital  of  beneficiaries,  will  help  in  addressing  equity  issues  by  ensuring  that  the 
needs  of  the  ultrapoor  are  explicitly  recognized  and  appropriate  development  alternatives 
offered to them. In addition, the Project will enhance the ability of nongovernment organizations 
(NGOs) to provide microfinance and support services to the beneficiaries. 
 
2. 
While  in  recent  years  Bangladesh  has  considerably  reduced  the  incidence  of  poverty, 
not all poor groups, particularly those in isolated rural areas, have benefited equally. The Project 
will go some way to addressing this deficiency.  
 
B. 
 
While  the  principal  objective  of  the  Project  is  poverty  reduction  in  the  broadest  sense, 
3. 
the main measure of the success of its activities is changes in household incomes. Toward this 
end,  the  main  project  activities  proposed  are  (i)  development  of  the  capacity  of  community 
leaders,  beneficiaries,  and  providers  of  support  services;  (ii)  technical,  microfinance,  and 
infrastructure support for both on- and off-farm activities; and (iii) strengthening the capacity of 
support  institutions  such  as  NGOs  and  the  Department  of  Livestock  Services  (DLS)  to  deliver 
services. 
 
The  analysis  that  follows  focuses  on  quantifiable  benefits  at  the  household  level  and 
4. 
describes nonquantifiable benefits in a qualitative manner. As the output from project-financed 
activities will largely be determined by a demand-driven process, it is difficult to predict the likely 
mix  and  scale  of  outputs.  Furthermore,  it  has  not  been  possible  to  quantify  the  long-term 
benefits of the human capital development activities to be undertaken as part of the community 
and capacity development components; neither has it been possible to quantify the outcome of 
the  proposed  innovation  and  ultrapoor  activities.  Therefore,  a  full  benefit-cost  analysis  for  the 
overall project was considered impractical. 
 
C. 
 
5. 
Communities to be targeted by the Project are in 20 districts in northwest Bangladesh, 
mainly  in  Rajshahi  division.1  The  districts  have  a  population  of  about  27  million,  including  6 
million  nonurban  households.  The  target  is  approximately  660,000  families  out  the  2.9  million 
households in the rural subdistricts covered by the Project. The Project will reach about 31% of 
the poverty-afflicted households in the subdistricts (poverty incidence is estimated at about 72% 
in  the  project  area).  The  indicative  figure  of  660,000  families  is  made  up  of  360,000  families 
from  districts  and  subdistricts  previously  covered  by  the  Participatory  Livestock  Development

Introduction  

A. 
 
This Summary Initial Environmental Examination (SIEE) records the major findings of an 
1. 
examination of the environmental impacts that may result from intervention activities proposed 
under  the  Project.  Information  gathered  during  field  visits  and  stakeholder  consultations,  and 
from a review of reports pertinent to the Project formed the basis for the SIEE. 
 
B. 

Description of the Project 

2. 
The  Project  will  carry  out  development  activities  in  20  districts  in  northwestern 
Bangladesh.  It  will  (i)  improve  community  capabilities  to  develop  and  manage  income- 
generating  activities  through  a  technical  and  social  development  training  program,  (ii)  provide 
microfinance and technical supporting services for rural enterprise development, (iii) assist the 
ultrapoor  through  a  pilot  program  of  asset  development  and  training,  (iv)  build  the  capacity  of 
the  Department  of  Livestock  Services,  and    (v)  support  the  Project’s  implementing  and 
management  agencies.  The  total  project  area  will  cover  157  subdistricts  in  20  districts;  68  of 
these  subdistricts  and  3  districts  are  areas  that  have  not  received  assistance  under  the 
Participatory Livestock Development Project.1 
 
C. 

Description of the Environment 

3. 
Water  Resources.  Flowing  rivers  and  standing  water  bodies  constitute  the  surface 
water  resources  of  the  project  area.  The  rivers  and  tributaries  cover  about  14%  of  the  project 
area. Water pollution problems are not apparent. 

4. 
Ecological  and  Cultural  Resources.  The  project  area  had  rich  flora  in  the  past.  But 
with  the  passage  of  time,  much  of  the  forest  has  disappeared  as  a  result  of  the  expansion  of 
agriculture  and  human  settlements.  The  project  districts  are  fairly  wooded  and  many  valuable 
forest trees are indigenous. The trees are used as timber and fuelwood. Clumps of bamboo are 
very common and are found in every homestead forest. A large variety of medicinal plants are 
also present.  
 
5. 
Large  mammals  like  tigers,  elephants,  gangetic  dolphins,  and  wild  boars  were  widely 
distributed  in  the  past,  but  have  almost  completely  disappeared.  Other  mammals  like  jackals, 
foxes, large Indian civets, otters, Bengal mongooses, and squirrels still occur, but their numbers 
are rapidly dwindling. Almost all varieties of birds found in Bangladesh are also common in the 
project area.  
 
There are places of aesthetic, historical, religious, cultural, and archeological value in the 
6. 
project  area.  Like  the  natural  forest  and  watersheds,  they  are  protected  under  the 
Environmental  Conservation  Act.  There  are  no  environmentally  sensitive  areas  in  the  project 
districts.

D. 

Screening of Potential Environment Impacts and Mitigation Measures 

7. 
A  masterscreening  checklist  drawn  up  for  agricultural  projects  in  Bangladesh  identified

components,  only  the  enterprise  development  component  has  potential  impacts.  The  impacts 
are outlined in paras. 8–11, with the appropriate mitigation and enhancement measures. 
 
8. 
Management  of  Polluting  Wastes.  Wastes  from  farm  activitities  using  veterinary 
vaccines and medicines, and chemical fertilizers are likely to create some pollution problem in 
the  natural  environment,  including  water,  soil,  and  ambient  air  around  the  farms.  Residual 
chemicals  from  vaccines  and  medicines  can  possibly  accumulate  and  ultimately  affect  human 
as  well  as  animal  health  by  entering  into  the  food  chain.  Training  beneficiaries  on  careful 
handling of polluting wastes can mitigate this potentially adverse impact.  

 
Treatment of Organic Wastes. All solid and liquid wastes generated on farms , contain 
9. 
organic pollutants. These are likely to be converted into organic fertilizer products, or neutralized 
by  natural  processes.  The  effluents  either  may  create  dissolved  oxygen  deficiency  in  water 
bodies and affect aquatic lives particularly fish, or may contaminate the soil. The best option for 
mitigating organic pollution is to construct biogas plants and use both solid and liquid wastes as 
raw  material  for  producing  energy  in  the  form  of  biogas.  However,  this  option  is  economically 
feasible  only  for  farms  with  more  than  250  chickens,  or  10  cattle.  Alternatively,  the  generated 
solid  wastes  can  be  used  in  preparing  compost  for  use  as  organic  fertilizer,  and  the  effluents 
can  be  neutralized  through  lagoon  treatment  in  earthen  ponds.  Farmers  generally  use  solid 
wastes  as  cooking  fuel;  however,  they  are  generally  less  familiar  with  composting techniques. 
Implementation  of  a  program  for  making  compost  will  require  some  technical  training  and 
assistance from either an experienced nongovernment organization (NGO) or the Department of 
Agriculture. 
 
10. 
Besides mitigating the impacts arising from organic waste disposal from existing farms, 
the  marketing  and  small  business  development  subcomponent  of  the  Project  will  promote  the 
construction  of  chilling,  pasteurizing  and  packaging  units,  and  slaughter  slabs  in  livestock-
owning  communities.  The  design  of  markets,  slaughter  slabs,  and  milk  treatment  stations  will 
include effective and environmentally sound waste and water disposal systems. Wastes (such 
as blood and intestinal contents) generated from slaughterhouses should produce no noticeable 
negative  impact  on  the  environment,  or  health;  rather  the  impact  is  expected  to  be  positive. 
Fishermen collect blood as fish feed, and the poor use intestinal contents as fuel and fertilizer.      

 

11. 
Increased  Forage  and  Fodder  Production  and  Soil  Conditioning.  Increased  forage 
production  and  establishment  of  leguminous  fodder  trees  in  farm  areas,  along  roadsides,  and 
fodder production pockets will help increase soil nitrogen and improve soil fertility and organic 
matter. This impact is positive; hence no mitigation will be required.

Findings and Recommendations 

to  raise 

15. 
The  important  environmental  impact  issues  arising  from  the  field  investigations  and 
stakeholder  consultations  include  the  following:  (i)  negative  impacts  due  to  unproductive 
management of livestock-generated wastes were common on all farms; (ii) no farms had waste 
treatment  facilities;  (iii) generated  solid  wastes are  deposited  in  earthen  ditches  and,  concrete 
containers,  or  heaped  in  the  open,  while  liquid  wastes  are  drained  into  closed  water  bodies, 
released  into  streams,  or  poured  on  the    ground;  (iv)  all  surveyed  farms  are  using  veterinary 
vaccines  and  medicines;  (v)  residues  from  these  farms  are  likely  to  produce  no  noticeable 
impact on the environment; and (vi) none of the surveyed farmers have any knowledge about 
the country’s environmental  policies and legislation. 
 
16. 
In  the  light  of  the  findings,  several  recommendations  can  be  made.  Farmers  need 
training  and  motivation  to  use  farm-generated  wastes  to  produce  biogas.  NGO  staff,  in 
cooperation  with  local  NGOs  and  the  Department  of  Agriculture,  must  train  farmers  on  the 
lagoon  treatment  for  generated  effluents,  and  compost  preparation  using  solid  and  semisolid 
wastes.  Farmers  require  awareness  training  to  comply  with  the  Department  of  Environment 
rules  and  regulations  on  farm  activities  and  waste  disposal.  Farmers  will  also  benefit  from 
training on the safe handling and health effects of veterinary vaccines and medicines, and the 
safe  preparation  of  poultry  and  cattle  feed  and  preservation  techniques.  Training  the 
implementing agency and NGO staff as trainers to regularly conduct community environmental 
awareness orientation will be useful.
